title: 112_s940
content: The Act is titled the "Close Big Oil Tax Loopholes Act" and includes a table of contents with various sections addressing findings and the Senate's stance on high gas prices. The Act, titled the "Close Big Oil Tax Loopholes Act," includes sections on modifications of foreign tax credit rules, limitations on deductions for oil and gas-related expenses, repeal of royalty relief on the outer Continental Shelf, and miscellaneous provisions for deficit reduction and budgetary effects. Congress finds that gas prices have risen significantly due to unrest in North Africa and the Middle East, leading to speculation and increased oil futures prices. High gas prices are negatively impacting the quality of life in the United States, affecting savings, jobs, and the economic recovery. Regulatory reforms to prevent energy market manipulation have been delayed, and the US is currently producing more oil than ever before. The United States is producing record amounts of oil, with companies holding abundant inventories. Despite this, the US still imports over 11 million barrels of oil per day. Domestic refining capacity exceeds demand, leading to increased idle refinery capacity. Oil companies are sitting on vast leased Federal lands with significant oil and natural gas reserves. The United States consumes 25% of the world's oil production despite having less than 2% of the world's proven oil reserves. The growing trade deficit in energy results in significant job and productivity losses. World oil prices are projected to remain high due to increasing global demand, especially from industrializing countries like China and India. OPEC's oil production policies also play a role in influencing prices. The United States economy is impacted by OPEC decisions as long as it relies on oil for energy consumption. Major oil companies have made significant profits and received tax breaks but have not invested much in clean and renewable fuel research. Congress increased fuel economy in the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007. In the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007, Congress increased fuel economy standards for the first time in 30 years and established requirements for domestic biofuels, reducing oil consumption and gas prices. The Senate expresses concern about high gas prices. The Senate commends the President for addressing high gas prices by taking actions such as promoting domestic production, investigating price gouging, setting a national oil savings goal, increasing electric vehicles, and harmonizing fuel standards. The Senate supports the President's efforts to address high gas prices by setting national oil savings goals, promoting electric vehicles, and expanding the use of alternative fuels like natural gas. Congress should also enact provisions to encourage responsible actions. The Senate aims to encourage responsible development of domestic oil and gas resources, eliminate subsidies for major oil companies, promote research on alternative fuels, provide more choices at the pump, and implement energy consumer protection requirements. The Consumer Protection Act emphasizes the need for OPEC to stabilize oil markets and reduce gasoline prices for US consumers. It also highlights the importance of reducing US dependency on oil for economic, environmental, and national security reasons. SEC. 101. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO MAJOR INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES WHICH ARE DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include special rules for major integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such taxpayers will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The amended Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces special rules for major integrated oil companies classified as dual capacity taxpayers. These taxpayers must pay income tax to a foreign country or possession of the United States, and any amount paid will not be considered a tax under specific conditions. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to individuals who meet certain criteria in relation to a foreign country or possession of the United States. The amended Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces special rules for major integrated oil companies classified as dual capacity taxpayers. These taxpayers must pay income tax to a foreign country or possession of the United States, and any amount paid will not be considered a tax under specific conditions. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to individuals who meet certain criteria in relation to a foreign country or possession of the United States. In this subsection, a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession, and receiving a specific economic benefit from that country or possession, is considered under generally applicable income tax rules. The amendments made by this section to Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, with exceptions for dual capacity taxpayers and citizens or residents of the foreign country or possession. These amendments do not apply if they conflict with any treaty obligations of the United States. SEC. 102. LIMITATION ON SECTION 199 DEDUCTION ATTRIBUTABLE TO OIL, NATURAL GAS, OR PRIMARY PRODUCTS THEREOF. Denial of Deduction for major integrated oil companies for gross receipts from oil, natural gas, or primary products. Effective for taxable years after December 31, 2011. SEC. 103. LIMITATION ON DEDUCTION FOR INTANGIBLE DRILLING AND DEVELOPMENT COSTS. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code excludes major integrated oil companies from deducting certain costs. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 104. LIMITATION ON PERCENTAGE DEPLETION ALLOWANCE FOR OIL AND GAS WELLS. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code states that major integrated oil companies will have a zero allowance for percentage depletion. Effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 105. LIMITATION ON DEDUCTION FOR TERTIARY INJECTANTS. SEC. 105. LIMITATION ON DEDUCTION FOR TERTIARY INJECTANTS. This section states that major integrated oil companies are exempt from deducting amounts paid for tertiary injectants in taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 is repealed, removing royalty relief for deep water and deep gas drilling on the outer continental shelf. The Secretary of the Interior is no longer required to provide royalty relief in lease sale terms. Additionally, there is a provision for deficit reduction in Title III. Title III of the Act focuses on deficit reduction. Any savings from the Act will be used to reduce the federal budget deficit or the federal debt at the discretion of the Secretary of the Treasury. The budgetary effects of the Act will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go-Act of 2010, submitted by the Chairman of the Senate Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
